moves.1. e4 b6 2. b3 Bb7 3. d3 g6 4. Bb2 Nf6 5: This somewhat compromised my pawn structure but I did get a Bishop for my Knight which may or may not be an even exhange.
moves.6. g3 Bb4+ 7. c3 Be7 8. Qc1 O-O 9. Bg2 d: My pieces are now where I like to place them in the opening.
moves.11. Nbd2 Ne5 12. Qc2 c5 13. O-O d5: To open the position up somewhat.
moves.14. Rae1 Ba6: Threatening the d3 square (if the pawn is still there then so much the better.)
moves.15. c4: Blocking the Queen's Bishop's line to d3.
moves.15... dxc4 16. bxc4 Qxd3: This is not how I intended to win the pawn at d3 but White kept putting an obstruction on c4.
moves.17. Rec1: Giving the c4 pawn enough protection that I turned my attention elsewhere,
moves.17... Nxf3+ 18. Nxf3 Rad8: Let him spend a tempo initiating a Queen exchange.
moves.19. Qa4: He opts not to exchange Queens.
moves.19... Bb7 20. Qxa7: He regained his pawn and is threatening my poor Bishop.
moves.20... Rdb8 21. Qxb6 Bxe4: Keeping the material balance for the moment.
moves.22. Qc7 Rfe8 23. Qf4: I am now thinking about his King's Rook coming to d1.
moves.23... f5 24. Rcd1 Qxc4: I really thought he would proceed with the King's Rook keeping c4 under surveillance.
moves.26. Rd2 Qe6 27. Re1: Now his shots at the e4 Bishop are too much and I decide the best course of action is a Bishop exchange.
moves.27... Bxg2 28. Kxg2 Bd6: Played to pin the Knight while attacking it three times.
moves.29. Rde2 f6: This puts the question to White.
moves.30. Nc6: He forcefully breaks the pin.  Quite honestly, I had expected Nc4.  The way the board sits now, I think I might be able to gain some material but only if I proceed aggressively.
moves.30... Qxe2 31. Qxd6 Qxe1 32. Nxb8: This recapture gave me pause, as I had planned to picked up the Knight with ---, Qe4+ ; K moves, Qxf6 and the White Queen needs to run.  Now winning the Knight will require some luck and effort.
moves.32... Qe4+ 33. Kg1: This the luck I wanted -- I really thought he would go to h3.  (Kf1 allows Qh1#.)
moves.33... Qb1+: Forking King and Knight, thus winning the Knight.
moves.34. Kg2 Rxb8: I wanted to maintain the Queen's ability to return to e4 with check.
moves.35. Qxc5: There was nothing to done for that pawn.
moves.35... Qe4+ 36. Kh3: The first rank would have been death after Rb1+.
moves.37. Qd6 g4+: This forces the King to surrender the g2 square.
moves.38. Kh4: At this point I really considered sacrificing the b8 Rook and going to g2, but upon further examination I decided that White would probably take the f6 pawn rather than the Rook so......
moves.38... Rf8 39. Kh5 Qg2: And now there is a bona fide mating net in play  --  although White can break it up by giving up his Queen.
moves.40. h4: Instead, White tries another approach that is consistent with Kh5
and probably did not count on this.
moves.41. Qd7 h2: At this point I considered the game most definitely won although White can drag it out somewhat.
